title: FCC12 lattice: isotropic 3D space backend
description: Add a Face-Centred Cubic (FCC) lattice backend to murk-space: 12 equidistant neighbours per cell, the most isotropic 3D discrete topology. This is the 3D analogue of Hex2D — single-distance neighbour set with minimal directional bias for diffusion, foveation, and pursuit dynamics. Integer coordinates (x,y,z) with parity constraint (x+y+z)%2==0, packed to dense indices via canonical_rank. Includes Absorb/Clamp/Wrap edge behaviour, compliance suite integration, FFI config wiring (SpaceType::Fcc12), and Python exposure.
notes: 14-step implementation plan across 4 phases: Core Backend (murk-space), FFI+Python Wiring, Integration Testing, Polish. Key decisions: parity constraint (x+y+z)%2==0, distance = max(max_abs, half_L1) (not L∞), even-dims-only for Wrap, Clamp degrades to Absorb at boundaries (parity safety), O(1) canonical_rank with even/odd z-slice alternation. SmallVec[Coord;8] spill accepted for v1. debug_assert guards on axis_distance_u32 and canonical_ordering for cheap misuse detection. Plan at docs/design/fcc12-lattice.md (Revision 4).
close_reason: FCC12 lattice implemented and pushed

title: Public Usability & Documentation
description: Make Murk accessible and usable to the public. Covers type stubs, API ergonomics, concepts documentation, examples, install story, and contributor onboarding. Gate for v1.0 public release.
close_reason: All 10 children complete: type stubs, enum API, concepts guide, examples (hex_pursuit, quickstart.rs, crystal_nav), rustdoc Pages, install story, CHANGELOG, CONTRIBUTING, richer error messages.

title: Python type stubs (.pyi)
description: Generate or hand-write .pyi stub files for the murk Python package. Every class, method, enum, and function exposed in __init__.py needs a typed stub. This is the single biggest barrier to Python usability — no autocomplete, no mypy, no IDE discoverability without it. Stubs should cover: Config, World, Command, Receipt, ObsEntry, ObsPlan, StepMetrics, PropagatorDef, MurkEnv, MurkVecEnv, all enums (SpaceType, FieldType, FieldMutability, EdgeBehavior, BoundaryBehavior, WriteMode, CommandType), and the add_propagator function. Consider using pyo3-stub-gen or writing manually.
close_reason: Type stubs (.pyi) and py.typed marker created, commit 1dfe031

title: Richer Python error messages with recovery hints
description: Improve error messages surfaced through the Python bindings. Currently errors come through as opaque MurkError strings from FFI status codes. Improvements: (1) Map FFI status codes to specific Python exception types (ValueError for invalid config, RuntimeError for engine failures). (2) Include recovery hints in error messages (e.g. DT_OUT_OF_RANGE should mention CFL constraint and suggest checking propagator max_dt). (3) Link to error-reference.md or published docs from error messages. (4) Ensure Python tracebacks point to user code, not internal FFI wrappers where possible.
close_reason: Rewrote check_status() with typed exceptions (ValueError/MemoryError/TimeoutError), recovery hints for all 19 error codes, and error-reference.md links. 3 unit tests. Commit b13095e.

title: Enum-ify Python API (eliminate magic integers)
description: Replace all raw integer parameters in the Python API with proper enum types. Key targets: (1) config.set_space() takes edge_behavior as float 0.0/1.0/2.0 — should accept EdgeBehavior enum. (2) ObsEntry region_type=0/5/6 — should accept a RegionType enum. (3) ObsEntry transform_type=0/1 — should accept a TransformType enum. (4) ObsEntry pool_kernel=0/1/2/3/4 — should accept a PoolKernel enum. (5) add_propagator writes=[(field, 0)] — write mode should accept WriteMode enum. (6) ObsEntry dtype=0 — should accept a DType enum. This may require adding new Python-side enums and updating the PyO3 bindings to accept both int and enum for backward compatibility, or just breaking to enums (preferred since pre-1.0).
close_reason: All magic integers replaced with enums: RegionType, TransformType, PoolKernel, DType for ObsEntry; WriteMode for PropagatorDef/add_propagator; typed set_space_* methods with EdgeBehavior. 6 commits, 70/71 tests pass (1 pre-existing flaky).

title: Concepts guide
description: Write a standalone concepts/architecture guide for users (not contributors). Should explain the mental model needed to use Murk effectively. Core sections: (1) Spaces & Topologies — what backends exist, how to choose, edge behaviors. (2) Fields & Mutability — Static/PerTick/Sparse, when to use each, performance implications. (3) Propagators — what they are, Euler vs Jacobi reads, write modes, ordering, pipeline validation. (4) Commands & Ingress — how actions enter the simulation, receipts, write modes. (5) Observations — ObsSpec→ObsPlan→execute pipeline, regions, transforms, pooling, foveation. (6) Runtime Modes — Lockstep vs RealtimeAsync, when to use each. (7) Arena & Memory — ping-pong, generations, snapshots (light touch, just enough to understand Sparse vs PerTick). Target: someone who has done the heat_seeker tutorial and wants to build something real.
close_reason: Concepts guide written at docs/CONCEPTS.md, commit aad5740

title: Additional examples
description: Add 2-3 more examples exercising different parts of the API that the heat_seeker tutorial doesn't cover. Each example should be self-contained with its own README. This is a parent for sub-beads covering individual examples.
close_reason: All children closed: hex_pursuit (4.1), quickstart.rs (4.2), crystal_nav (4.3)

title: Example: Hex pursuit (Hex2D + multi-agent + foveation)
description: A Python example on a Hex2D grid with 2+ agents: one predator, one prey (or cooperative pursuit). Demonstrates: Hex2D space backend, multi-agent observation via execute_agents, AgentDisk region for local perception (foveation), multi-agent command submission, and competitive/cooperative reward design. Should show how observation size stays constant even on larger grids thanks to local perception.
close_reason: Hex pursuit example at examples/hex_pursuit/, commit f2f7273

title: Example: Rust propagator (diffusion in pure Rust)
description: A Rust example that implements a custom propagator in Rust (not Python trampoline), builds a LockstepWorld, and runs it. Demonstrates: implementing the Propagator trait, declaring reads/reads_previous/writes, using StepContext, field access patterns. Should contrast with the Python propagator in heat_seeker to show the performance path. Can be a binary in examples/ or a standalone crate with murk dependencies.
close_reason: Covered by quickstart.rs (18bdba6) — implements Propagator trait with reads_previous/writes, StepContext field access, discrete diffusion in pure Rust

title: Example: 3D volumetric (ProductSpace or FCC12)
description: A Python example using FCC12 for a 3D volumetric environment. Demonstrates: FCC12 3D lattice (12 equidistant neighbours, parity constraint), 3D observation extraction, 3D agent movement with 12 directional actions. Could model 3D pursuit, atmospheric diffusion, or volumetric foraging. FCC12 is now implemented (murk-04q closed). Alternatively could show ProductSpace (e.g. Hex2D x Line1D) as a second topology in the same example or a variant section.

title: Decide 0.x vs 1.x semantic versioning strategy

Need to decide: stay at 0.x (API not stable, normal for early Rust projects) or commit to 1.x (stable API guarantee). This decision gates the tag fix (murk-rgw). Most Rust projects stay 0.x until API churn settles.
close_reason: Decision: stay at 0.x. API not yet stable. Deleted incorrect 1.0.0 tag, will create v0.1.0.

Cargo workspace with all 9 crate stubs, CI pipeline, test framework, clippy configuration.

title: WP-9: Python Bindings
description:
PyO3 wrapping C ABI with GIL release, NumPy integration, Gymnasium interface.

Complexity: M | Hard deps: WP-8 | Milestone: M1
HLD refs: R-FFI-2, R-FFI-5, §18
Design refs: IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §6.10 (Gymnasium spaces derivation: observation_space from ObsPlan, action_space user-provided)

Deliverables:
- murk-python crate (PyO3): MurkEnv(gymnasium.Env) with step/reset/observation_space/action_space
- MurkEnv constructor: MurkEnv(config, obs_spec, n_actions, action_space=None) (§6.10)
- observation_space: derived from compiled ObsPlan output shape (gym.spaces.Box)
- action_space: user-provided (NOT derived from world config — actions are domain-specific)
- MurkVecEnv(gymnasium.vector.VectorEnv) with auto-reset
- GIL released via py.allow_threads() on all C ABI calls
- NumPy buffer integration (caller-allocated, zero-copy)
- Context manager for handle lifecycle
- env.last_step_metrics property (§6.11)

Acceptance: GIL release verified. Gymnasium compliance. NumPy buffer correct. PPO smoke test (100K steps, single agent, 10×10 Square4, reward = negative Manhattan distance).
close_reason: WP-9 Python bindings completed and signed off - PyO3 + Gymnasium adapter + PPO smoke test

Hex2D lattice backend + ProductSpace composition with dual distance API.

- WP-10b (murk-ylw.11.2): ProductSpace (L) — Vec<Box<dyn Space>>, per-component neighbours, L1 geodesic distance, lexicographic iteration, Cartesian product regions. Depends on WP-10a.

title: WP-10a: Hex2D Backend
description:
Hex2D lattice backend with axial coordinates.

Complexity: M | Milestone: M3
HLD refs: R-SPACE-4, R-SPACE-6, R-SPACE-7
Design refs: IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §6.6 (RegionSpec/RegionPlan)

Deliverables:
- Hex2D backend: axial coordinates (q, r), 6 neighbours
- Cube-distance metric
- Canonical ordering: r-then-q
- compile_region() for hex regions: Disk produces hexagonal shape, Rect produces bounding box
- Hex tensor export: bounding box + validity mask, branch-free gather with precomputed index tables
- RegionPlan valid_ratio ≈ 0.75 for large hex disk radius

Acceptance:
- 6 neighbours in documented order
- Distance matches BFS (cube distance = graph geodesic)
- valid_ratio converges to ~0.75 for large R (hex disk in rectangular bounding box)
- Pass Space trait compliance tests from WP-3a
- v1 hex shapes: rectangles + disks only (Decision #22, wrap-around deferred to v1.5)
close_reason: Hex2D backend complete: axial coords, 6 neighbours, cube distance, hex disk regions, compliance tests pass

title: WP-10b: ProductSpace Composition
description:
ProductSpace composition with dual distance API.

Complexity: L | Milestone: M3 | Depends on: WP-10a (Hex2D)
HLD refs: R-SPACE-8 through R-SPACE-12, §11.1, §12
Design refs: IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §6.6 (RegionSpec/RegionPlan)

Deliverables:
- ProductSpace: stores components as Vec<Box<dyn Space>> (Decision M, vtable dispatch)
- Per-component neighbours (R-SPACE-8)
- L1 graph-geodesic distance (R-SPACE-9)
- metric_distance() with configurable metrics
- Lexicographic iteration (R-SPACE-10)
- Region queries as Cartesian products (R-SPACE-11)
- valid_ratio computation: product of per-component ratios
- Worked examples from HLD §11.1 as acceptance tests

Acceptance:
- Hex2D×Line1D: distance, neighbours, iteration match HLD §11.1 worked examples
- Property tests: distance metric axioms, neighbour symmetry, BFS = geodesic
- valid_ratio ≥ 0.35 for all v1 compositions
- Hex2D×Hex2D ≈ 0.56 (warns, doesn't fail)
- Start with 2-component, add 3-component only after 2 is solid (Risk #5)
close_reason: ProductSpace complete: Cartesian product, L1/LInfinity/Weighted metrics, BFS disk, all HLD worked examples verified

title: WP-11: Foveation and Standard ObsPlan
description:
Agent-centred observation windows, pooling, Standard plan class, FlatBuffers ObsSpec.

Complexity: L | Hard deps: WP-7, WP-10 | Milestone: M3
HLD refs: §16.1, §16.3

Deliverables:
- Agent-relative regions with interior/boundary dispatch (O(1) check, ~90% interior for radius < grid/4)
- Pooling operations

- ObsPlan caching with rate-limited recompilation

- execute_batch() interface (§6.9): single traversal fills N agent buffers. v1: N sequential calls internally. v1.5: single traversal.

Acceptance: Interior/boundary dispatch functional equivalence. Hex foveation correct. FlatBuffers round-trip. execute_batch with N agents produces correct per-agent observations.
close_reason: WP-11 complete: Standard plan class with agent-centered foveation, pooling, interior/boundary dispatch, FlatBuffers serialization, FFI+Python bindings. 82 murk-obs tests + 51 murk-ffi tests pass.

title: WP-12: RealtimeAsync Mode
description:
RealtimeAsyncWorld with TickEngine thread, egress pool, epoch reclamation.

Complexity: XL | Hard deps: WP-5, WP-7 | Milestone: M4 | Risk: HIGH
HLD refs: R-MODE-1, §7.2, §8.2, §8.3, P-1, P-3
Design refs: docs/design/epoch-reclamation.md (COMPLETE DESIGN: epoch mechanism, shutdown state machine, adaptive backoff, thread pool, memory bound proof, testing strategy)

Deliverables:
- RealtimeAsyncWorld: TickEngine on dedicated thread
- Custom lightweight epoch mechanism (~200 lines, not crossbeam-epoch) — see epoch-reclamation.md §1-5
- Snapshot ring buffer (default K=8, configurable; count + byte-budget eviction)
- Egress thread pool: fixed-size (num_cpus/2, min 2, max 16), WorkerEpoch with pin/unpin/cancel — see §3, §7
- Stalled worker detection + teardown: last_quiesce timestamp, max_epoch_hold=100ms, cancel_grace=10ms — see §6
- Cancellation checked between region iterations (not per-cell) — see §6
- Memory bound: live_generations ≤ K + S (proved in §8)
- 60Hz wall-clock deadline, fallback snapshot selection
- ttl_ms → expires_after_tick conversion, adaptive max_tick_skew (§10)
- Backpressure policy (R-MODE-2)
- Graceful shutdown: 4-state machine Running→Draining(≤33ms)→Quiescing(≤200ms)→Dropped(≤10ms) — see §9
- tick_disabled integration (Decision J) — see §9
- RealtimeMetrics telemetry (§6.11): tick_duration_us, queue_depth, snapshot_age_ticks, rejection_count, current_max_skew

Acceptance: 60Hz sustained under reference profile. P-1 (stalled workers → ObsError::ExecutionFailed with WORKER_STALLED). Stress tests §23 #15-17 (§6.13). Memory bounded.
close_reason: RealtimeAsync mode fully implemented: tick_thread.rs (tick loop, adaptive backoff, stall detection), egress.rs (worker pool with epoch pin/unpin), realtime.rs (RealtimeAsyncWorld API, shutdown state machine), config.rs (AsyncConfig). 97 tests passing (3x). crossbeam-channel added. Zero unsafe, zero warnings.

title: WP-13: Replay System
description:
Replay log format, recording, playback, determinism CI framework.

Complexity: M | Hard deps: WP-1, WP-5 | Soft deps: WP-6 (Lockstep target) | Milestone: M4
HLD refs: R-DET-1 through R-DET-6, §14.3-14.4, §19.1
Design refs: IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §6.12 (complete replay log format: binary header + frame stream, snapshot hash verification, per-field divergence reporting)

Deliverables:
- murk-replay crate: custom binary format (§6.12)
- Header: magic b"MURK", format_version u32, build metadata (toolchain, ISA, flags), init descriptor (seed, config_hash, field_count, cell_count)
- Per-tick frame: tick_id, command_count, serialized commands with ordering provenance, snapshot_hash (u64)
- ReplayWriter, ReplayReader
- Snapshot comparison: logical field values via SnapshotAccess::read_field() (not arena-level bytes)
- CI replay-and-compare: per-tick bit-exact comparison with first-divergence reporting (tick ID, field ID, byte offset)
- Determinism source catalogue (R-DET-6)

Acceptance: All 8 determinism replay scenarios pass (5 MUST + 3 SHOULD). 1000+ tick minimum. First-divergence reporting complete.
close_reason: Replay system fully implemented: error.rs (7 error variants), types.rs (BuildMetadata, InitDescriptor, Frame, SerializedCommand, 7 payload type constants), codec.rs (LE binary encode/decode with proptest round-trips), hash.rs (FNV-1a snapshot_hash + config_hash), writer.rs (ReplayWriter<W: Write>), reader.rs (ReplayReader<R: Read> + FrameIter), compare.rs (compare_snapshot + replay_and_compare with DivergenceReport). 31 unit tests, 8 integration determinism scenarios (5 MUST + 3 SHOULD), all passing with 1000+ ticks. docs/determinism-catalogue.md written. Zero clippy warnings, zero doc warnings.

title: WP-2: Arena Allocator
description:
Generational arena with segmented bump allocation, double-buffer ping-pong, sparse slab, static gen-0 arena.

Deliverables:
- murk-arena crate: ReadArena (Send+Sync), WriteArena (&mut)
- FieldHandle with embedded generation:u32 for O(1) validity checking (§6.5)
- Segmented arena: 64MB segments, grow-on-demand, max_segments=16 (1GB cap) (§6.5)
- Double-buffer ping-pong for Lockstep (§5.6)
- Sparse slab: free-list based, generation-tracked, epoch-gated reclamation (§6.5)
- Static arena: Arc<StaticArena> wrapping Vec<f32>, shared across vectorized envs (§6.5)
- ScratchRegion bump allocator
- Implements FieldReader for ReadArena and FieldWriter for WriteArena

Phase 1: Vec<f32> zero-init. Phase 2: MaybeUninit<f32> + FullWriteGuard after WP-4.

Acceptance: Property tests (arbitrary field counts/sizes/generations round-trip). Handle from gen N invalid after gen N+2. Static fields share allocation (pointer equality). Memory bound: after N ticks, size ≤ 2× PerTick + 1× Static + Sparse slab. Miri clean. Unsafe ≤5 functions in raw.rs.
close_reason: Arena allocator implemented: 12 files, 60 tests, 0 warnings, 0 clippy issues, 0 unsafe

close_reason: Propagator pipeline implemented: Propagator trait (object-safe, &self, Send+'static), StepContext with split-borrow dyn dispatch, ScratchRegion bump allocator, FullWriteGuard with debug coverage tracking, ReadResolutionPlan (precomputed overlay routing), pipeline validation (write conflicts, field refs, dt constraints). 3 test fixtures in murk-test-utils (Identity, Const, Failing). 26 tests, 0 warnings, 0 clippy issues, 0 unsafe.

title: WP-5: TickEngine Core
description:
Central tick execution: drain ingress → validate → run propagators → publish snapshot.

Complexity: L | Hard deps: WP-2, WP-4 | Soft deps: WP-3 (Square4 for testing) | Milestone: M0
HLD refs: R-ARCH-1, R-ARCH-3, §9.1
Design refs: IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §6.1 (CommandPayload), §6.7 (ReadResolutionPlan), §6.8 (WorldConfig), §6.11 (StepMetrics)

Sub-packages:
- WP-5a (murk-ylw.6.1): Command Processing (M) — ingress drain, ordering, TTL, receipts
- WP-5b (murk-ylw.6.2): Tick Execution + Atomicity (L) — ReadResolutionPlan, overlay resolution, tick atomicity, tick_disabled. HIGHEST RISK ITEM.

Critical: Overlay resolution via precomputed ReadResolutionPlan (§6.7) — zero runtime conditionals. Built at startup, routes each (propagator, field) to BaseGen or Staged{writer_index}.
notes: WP-5a complete (infrastructure + command processing). WP-5b (tick execution + atomicity) remaining.
close_reason: Both sub-packages (WP-5a, WP-5b) complete. Tick engine with overlay resolution, atomicity, and rollback fully implemented and passing 51 tests.

title: WP-5a: Command Processing
description:
Command processing subsystem: ingress drain, validation, ordering, receipt generation.

Complexity: M | Milestone: M0
HLD refs: R-CMD-1, R-CMD-2, R-ACT-1, R-ACT-2, §14.2
Design refs: IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §6.1 (CommandPayload enum), §6.8 (WorldConfig)

Deliverables:
- Ingress bounded queue (max_ingress_queue from WorldConfig, default 1024)
- Command drain with expires_after_tick (TTL) evaluation
- Deterministic ordering: priority_class → source_id/source_seq → arrival_seq (stable sort)
- arrival_seq monotonic counter
- Receipt generation with accepted/applied_tick_id/reason_code/command_index
- CommandPayload processing: WorldEvent variants (Move, Spawn, Despawn, SetField, Custom) + GlobalParameter variants (SetParameter, SetParameterBatch)
- ParameterKey validation (reject unknown keys at ingress)

Acceptance:
- Command ordering unit tests (priority, source disambiguation, arrival_seq tiebreak)
- TTL rejection test (expired → STALE receipt)
- Property test: arbitrary command batches sorted deterministically
- Receipt fields complete per §14.2
- Queue overflow → QUEUE_FULL error
- Independently testable without propagators or arena
close_reason: IngressQueue with bounded capacity, deterministic ordering, TTL evaluation, and receipt generation. 16 unit tests + 1 proptest, all passing.

title: WP-5b: Tick Execution + Atomicity
description:
Tick execution engine with overlay resolution, atomicity, and snapshot publication.

Complexity: L | Milestone: M0 | Depends on: WP-5a (Command Processing)
HLD refs: R-ARCH-1, R-ARCH-3, §9.1
Design refs: IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §6.7 (ReadResolutionPlan), §6.8 (WorldConfig)

HIGHEST-RISK ITEM IN THE PROJECT. The ReadResolutionPlan (§6.7) is ~50-100 lines with the highest correctness criticality in the engine.

Deliverables:
- Precomputed ReadResolutionPlan built at startup (§6.7): maps (propagator_index, field_id) → ReadSource (BaseGen or Staged{writer_index})
- Write-write conflict detection at plan construction time
- Propagator execution in dependency order with overlay resolution
- Tick atomicity: all-or-nothing via arena abandon on propagator failure
- Commands dropped with TICK_ROLLBACK on failure (not re-enqueued)
- Snapshot descriptor publication
- Configurable NaN sentinel check on written fields (off by default, HLD §9.2)
- consecutive_rollback_count tracking + tick_disabled mechanism (Decision J): AtomicBool after 3 consecutive rollbacks; ingress rejects with TICK_DISABLED; recovery via reset()
- murk_consecutive_rollbacks() C ABI query function

Acceptance:
- Three-propagator overlay visibility test (5 cases per IMPLEMENTATION-PLAN.md §2 WP-5):
  A writes X → B reads X via reads() sees A's value
  B reads X via reads_previous() sees base gen
  C reads X sees B's staged value if B wrote
  etc.
- ReadResolutionPlan unit test (precomputed routing correct)
- Tick atomicity test (propagator failure → no snapshot, state unchanged)
- Criterion: full tick cycle on reference profile
close_reason: TickEngine implemented with overlay resolution, tick atomicity, rollback tracking, and all 21 new tests passing. BaseFieldCache+StagedFieldCache+OverlayReader pattern resolves the borrow conflict. 49 total engine tests, 244 workspace tests, zero clippy warnings.
